#T_SP=webanno.custom.Referent|entity|infstat
#T_RL=webanno.custom.Coref|type|BT_webanno.custom.Referent
#Text=Introduce New Pets
#Text=Even the most gentle pets have trouble accepting a new pet .
#Text=Introduce new pets slowly and under supervision .
#Text=Steps
#Text=Research the realistic compatibility of your new pet being housed with your old pets , preferably before you select your new pet .
#Text=In addition to predator/prey relationships , some animals can be very territorial and aggressive towards members of their own species .
#Text=Learn what you can beforehand and you 'll have a better idea of how much peaceful interaction you can expect your animals to have .
#Text=Consider the personality of your current pet or pets .
#Text=Think about how your pet acts around you and around other animals .
#Text=Give your new pet as much time as possible to adjust before meeting your current pet .
#Text=Moving into a new home is enough of a challenge without the added stress of meeting your other pets .
#Text=If you can , set aside a room for your new pet to stay in for the first few days .
#Text=Keep your current pet 's schedule as normal as possible .
#Text=If you are going to house your new pet in a separate room to start with , restrict the current pet 's access to that room well in advance so the change can feel more gradual .
#Text=Make sure your current pet still gets all the time care and attention he or she is accustomed to .
#Text=Look for " pre-introduction " opportunities .
#Text=Give each animal items with the scent of the other animal on them .
#Text=Allowing the animals to smell each others ' scent before they actually meet can help make the face to face meeting easier .
#Text=Introduce animals slowly and for small periods of time until they are well adjusted to the sight and smell of each other .
#Text=Use a crate , child gate , or a leash to control the animals during the interactions .
#Text=Try to keep the animal who has the most potential to hurt the other one under direct control , either through a leash or a crate .
#Text=Give the animal that is more likely to be frightened a safe haven where the other pet cannot reach him or her .
#Text=Reward good behavior .
#Text=Remember that not all animals are going to be friends , so even disinterest is positive .
#Text=Offer praise , treats , toys , and affection to promote good interactions
#Text=Supervise closely .
#Text=Do n't just throw your animals together and go watch television .
#Text=Pay attention to the way they interact during different times of the introduction .
#Text=Be patient .
#Text=Animals need time to adjust to each other , especially if your old pet is older and the new pet is a baby .
#Text=It might take months before your animals really begin to accept each other .
#Text=Tips
#Text=Frequent interaction is not necessarily going to work for all pets , but they can still share a house if precautions are taken .
#Text=Your cat may always want to chase your hamster .
#Text=You can still have both as long as the hamster is safe in his or her cage and can come out for exercise without the cat being in the room .
#Text=Make sure you have adequate space and housing for both animals to live separately .
#Text=Though you may intend for the animals to share a room or cage eventually , this may not be possible right away , or ever .
#Text=Even animals who get along quite well may not be willing to share their " dens " .
#Text=Keep it positive .
#Text=If you 're constantly correcting one animal during an introduction , that animal will come to associate the other one with negative things .
#Text=Remove an animal who is n't behaving from the situation and go back to scent-only introductions or put the animal somewhere secure so the bad behavior can be ignored .
#Text=These same steps can be used to introduce a new animal to small children .
#Text=Keep children and the new animal separate until the new pet adjusts to your child 's voice and movements .
#Text=Research age appropriate pets for the age range your children are .
#Text=Make sure training you intend to use when introducing the animals , such as a crate , leash , or muzzle , is introduced ahead of time .
#Text=You do n't want to be putting a muzzle on a dog who 's never worn one before and add to this new and possibly uncomfortable experience by having her meet the new cat for the first time .
#Text=If they are of the same species , you ca n't guarantee they will tend to get along .
#Text=Try to build social bonds between the pets , and they may naturally learn on their own they should get along with each other .
#Text=Warnings
#Text=Some animals will simply not get along no matter how much you try .
#Text=For these situations , you 'll have to make a choice .
#Text=Can you keep everyone safe and without stress or does your new pet need to find a new home ?
#Text=Never leave two animals together unsecured and unsupervised unless you are certain they are ready for it .
#Text=One animal could seriously injure or even kill the other .
